awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Fundamental Algorithms for Data-Limited Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
From medical imaging to astronomy, scientific hypothesis testing to data analysis, computers are used in a wide variety of areas where computation is cheaper than data collection.  Such situations call for algorithms that are not only fast, but also data efficient. This project considers sub-linear algorithms for fundamental computational problems of interest in both theory and practice. It focuses on two basic questions: how many samples, or noisy observations from a signal, does it take to accurately reconstruct the signal, and how many samples from an object does it take to estimate a property of the object?

The PI will investigate ways to leverage knowledge of signal structure into improved signal reconstruction.  An example signal structure is the property of having a sparse Fourier transform; this has been well studied in the discrete setting, but is still poorly understood in the more realistic continuous setting. Another signal structure is that given by generative models built with deep convolutional neural networks; these have produced remarkably accurate models of images in recent years.  This project will use such models to estimate images more accurately from fewer measurements.  The PI will also investigate problems in distribution testing and graph sampling, with a goal of translating techniques from the distribution testing literature into the statistical hypothesis testing framework.  The PI will incorporate research into teaching, and mentor students at levels ranging from high school to graduate school.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
This project studied how to make the most efficient use of limited
data and computer memory when solving important measurement
problems. The research explored two main themes that advance both
fundamental science and practical applications.

The first theme focused on using modern developments in deep
generative AI to improve imaging technology, such as in MRI scans. MRI
machines can only take a limited number of measurements, which can be
noisy or imperfect. Our research showed how to use modern artificial
intelligence techniques, specifically recent advances in AI image
generation, to reconstruct high-quality medical images from fewer,
noisier measurements. We developed new mathematical theories that help
explain both what's possible with these techniques and what their
fundamental limitations are. This work could eventually lead to faster
MRI scans or clearer images from the same scanning time.

The second theme investigated when and how measuring systems can be
improved by making them "adaptive"--meaning they can adjust what they
measure based on previous measurements. We studied this question
across several scenarios, from efficient disease testing to processing
large streams of data. In some cases, we found that carefully designed
fixed measurement strategies work just as well as adaptive ones, while
in other cases, adaptive measurements provide major benefits. For
example, we developed new methods for group testing (where multiple
samples are tested together to save time and resources) that are both
fast and reliable even when the measurements are noisy.  We also
created new algorithms for handling large "turnstile" streams of data
that outperform previous methods by adapting to patterns in the data;
prior work generally believed that nonadaptive methods were nearly
optimal, but we showed how to use adaptivity to make a big
improvement.


Last Modified: 11/29/2024
Modified by: Eric Price
